{{Infobox military person | honorific_prefix=[[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]] | name = Museyib Baghir oglu Baghirov | native_name = Müseyib Bağır oğlu Bağırov | birth_date = 30 June 1915 | death_date = {{deathdateandage|1981|5|17|1915|6|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Yelizavetpol]], [[Yelizavetpol Governorate]], [[Russian Empire]] | death_place = [[Baku]], [[Azerbaijan SSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | allegiance = Soviet Union | branch = [[Red Army]] | serviceyears = 1941{{endash}}1945 | rank = [[Captain (armed forces)|Captain]] | unit = [[69th Guards Rifle Division]] | battles = {{plainlist| *[[World War II]] *[[Battle of Kursk]] *[[Battle of the Dnieper]] }} | awards = {{plainlist| *{{Hero of the Soviet Union}} Hero of the Soviet Union *{{Order of Lenin}} Order of Lenin }} }}
'''Museyib Baghir oglu Baghirov''' ({{Lang-az|Müseyib Bağır oğlu Bağırov}}; 30 June 1915{{En dash}}17 May 1981) was an [[Azerbaijanis|Azerbaijani]] [[Red Army]] [[Captain (armed forces)|captain]] and a [[Hero of the Soviet Union]]. Baghirov was awarded the title on 22 February 1944 for his actions during the [[Battle of the Dnieper]], in which his platoon reportedly killed up to 250 German soldiers and destroyed three tanks. Postwar, Baghirov was demobilized and worked in the oil industry.<ref name=":0">{{Ruheroes|id=4452}}</ref>
== Early life == Baghirov was born on 30 June 1915 in [[Yelizavetpol]] in the family of a textile worker. He graduated from junior high school in 1931 and moved to [[Baku]], where he graduated from the Naval College. He returned to Ganja (renamed Kirovabad) and worked as an assistant foreman at the Kirovabad Textile Combine.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=http://www.az-libr.ru/index.htm?Persons&103/ee636deb/index|title=Герои Советского Союза: Краткий биографический словарь|last=|first=|publisher=Voenizdat|year=1987|isbn=|editor-last=Shkadov|editor-first=Ivan|volume=1 Abaev-Lubitsch|location=Moscow|page=102|pages=|language=Russian|trans-title=Heroes of the Soviet Union: A Brief Biographical Dictionary|via=}}</ref>
== World War II == Baghirov was drafted into the Red Army in 1941. He fought in combat from November 1942 in battles on the [[Volga River]]. Baghirov was sent to the [[Kemerovo]] Infantry School and graduated from an accelerated course in 1943. He was sent to the front as a platoon leader in the 206th Guards Rifle Regiment of the [[69th Guards Rifle Division]].<ref name=":1" /> Baghirov fought in the [[Battle of Kursk]].<ref name=":0" />
Baghirov fought in the Battle of the Dnieper. On 9 September, southwest of [[Zinkiv]], he reportedly captured an important height leading 11 other soldiers. During the battle, Baghirov reportedly killed 28 German soldiers with a sniper rifle. He reportedly destroyed an anti-tank gun and killed its crew with grenades. The platoon reportedly held the height for the rest of the day, destroying 3 tanks and killing up to 250 German soldiers. Baghirov was wounded, but reportedly did not leave the battlefield. He was later evacuated to a hospital. In 1944, he joined the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]]. On 22 February 1944 he was awarded the title Hero of the Soviet Union and the [[Order of Lenin]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>Hero of the Soviet Union citation, available online at [https://pamyat-naroda.ru/heroes/podvig-chelovek_nagrazhdenie46245433/ pamyat-naroda.ru]</ref>
After recovering from his wound, Baghirov returned to the regiment. He fought through the rest of the war and was seriously wounded in both hands and head at the end of the war. Baghirov spent almost eight months in the hospital and was demobilized in October 1945 with the rank of captain.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Postwar == Baghirov moved to Baku and graduated from the Commercial College. For several years, he worked as head of geological exploration in the Neftechalaneft oilfields. Baghirov survived a fall from a 25 meter tower but was unable to engage in physical labor afterwards. He began working in the Karadagneft Workers' Supply Department. Baghirov later worked as director of a department store in [[Lökbatan]] and then at the Gastronom store in Baku. He died on 17 May 1981.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
== Personal life == Baghirov married and had two daughters, Raya Babayeva and Sitara Baghirova.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.trend.az/life/socium/2530879.html|title=Азербайджанцы были настоящими героями! – дочери Героя Советского Союза|last=Imanov|first=Vugar|date=9 May 2016|website=|publisher=Trend News Agency|language=ru-RU|trans-title=Azerbaijanis were the real heroes! - Daughters of the Hero of the Soviet Union|access-date=2016-07-31}}</ref>
== References == <references /> [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:1981 deaths]] [[Category:Heroes of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Soviet Army officers]] [[Category:Soviet military personnel of World War II from Azerbaijan]] [[Category:People from Ganja, Azerbaijan]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin]] [[Category:Communist Party of the Soviet Union members]] {{DEFAULTSORT:Baghirov, Museyib}}
